contents.name: Bronze

weapon_effect.base: Produces an audible chime when hitting a target, alerting creatures within 10 feet.

contents.description: A shiny brown-ish colored metal alloy of tin and copper, known for its resonance.

contents.name: Silver

weapon_effect.base: Ignores some creature resistances, most notably were-creatures.

contents.description: A common precious metal often used to make coins, especially effective against shapechangers.

contents.name: Banglum

weapon_effect.base: When you hit a creature or object with an attack, once per turn, you can deal 1d4 damage to each creature or object (non-held and non-worn) of your choice within 5 feet of the target. The damage type is the same as the weapon’s damage type

contents.description: A brown, unstable metal, theorized to be a lesser form of Scoria.

contents.name: Untempered Arandur
contents.description: A blue-green streaked metal appearing in hyaline glass pockets, refined to a silver-blue color.

contents.name: Cold Iron

weapon_effect.base: A weapon made from cold iron ignores bludgeoning, slashing, or piercing damage resistances of creatures with the fey subtype and deals an additional 1d4 damage on hits with them

contents.description: A precious metal mined in areas touched by dark magic, especially effective against fey.

contents.name: Ceramite

weapon_effect.base: Bypasses same resistances as Adamantine, deals extra damage to objects.weapons bypass the same monster resistances that Adamantine does, and when you hit an object with a Ceramite weapon you may add double your damage modifier to the damage of the attack, rather than adding it just once.

contents.description: An alloy known as a ‘poor man’s adamantine’ with strong elemental resistance properties.

contents.name: Mithril

weapon_effect.base: Weapons lose the heavy property or gain the light property; items weigh half as much.

contents.description: A silver-and-black mineral that becomes silvery-blue when forged, favored by dwarves.

contents.name: Magnetite

weapon_effect.base: A weapon made from magnetite may be used as a compass, as the tip of the weapon orients itself northward. Additionally, if this weapon is used to push an enemy (E.g. a Pushing Attack, Shove action made with a weapon, etc.), the enemy takes 1d4 magical bludgeoning damage per 10 feet forcefully moved.

contents.description: A natural lodestone, valuable to adventurers and navigators.

contents.name: Impure Siderite

weapon_effect.base: Can be used as a Divine Foci

contents.description: An alloy of blessed metal, silver and gold, uniquely crafted most often by forge clerics.

contents.name: Ilythiiri Ebony

weapon_effect.base: When you hit a target who is concentrating on a spell, they have disadvantage on the concentration saving throw.

contents.description: A jet black metal as an ore, and becomes black with a blue sheen when forged.

contents.name: Gold

weapon_effect.base: You ignore resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage from incorporeal creatures.

contents.description: Known for its relative softness for a metal, beauty and its resistance to corrosion. As such, it's long enjoyed being associated with purity, wealth and the divine.

contents.name: Electrum
contents.description: A highly conductive dull blue metal, widely used for enchanting.

contents.name: Adamantine

weapon_effect.base: Bypasses resistances; automatically crits on objects.

contents.description: A jet-black alloy of adamant with unique sheen depending on light source.

contents.name: Scoria

weapon_effect.base: Deals extra fire damage on critical hits; causes fire damage on crit fails.

contents.description: A pulsating red-orange unstable metal, dangerous yet powerful.

contents.name: Auramite

weapon_effect.base: Forces disadvantage on concentration saves; bypasses certain resistances.

contents.description: An alloy of meteoric ores and blessed metals, highly effective against extraplanar beings.

contents.name: Achrondrite

weapon_effect.base: weapons made of achondrite have their normal weapon damage type replaced with fire.

contents.description: This metal is often confused for a stone, due to its gray coloration and flakey nature.

contents.name: Tempered Arandur

weapon_effect.base: A weapon made of tempered arandur is immune to any decaying, rusting or rotting effect, even by that of deities.

contents.description: A naturally brittle metal, but when tempered in the blood of a red or blue dragon, it dramatically increases the toughness of the weapon.

contents.name: Orichalcum

weapon_effect.base: When you attack a creature that possesses a swim speed, the attack deals an extra 1d12 of bane damage with an additional bonus equal to the enhancement bonus of the weapon. Double this additional damage if the creature only has a swim speed.

contents.description: Appearing as either a dark yellow or reddish-yellow metal, said to be the exact color of a blazing fire.

contents.name: Pure Siderite

weapon_effect.base: Weapons made from pure siderite deal an extra 2d6 damage on the first attack made on the target after entering melee range and on attacks made as part of a reaction.

contents.description: A metal made of streaking silver and gold lines, that shine brilliantly under light.

contents.name: Starfall Ore

weapon_effect.base: Indestructible; gains attack bonuses at night and meteor showers.

contents.description: The rarest of the three star-born metals, desired by kings and demigods.

contents.name: Mizzium

weapon_effect.base: If the weapon has the heavy property it deals additional damage equal to half the users strength mod (rounded down), and if the weapon has the finesse property it deals extra damage equal to half the users dexterity mod (rounded down).

contents.description: Crafting mizzium requires the innate magic of a fully grown adult dragon with a fire based breath weapon to superheat the metal while crafting, meaning the dragon must be available during the whole time of crafting and practically ensures that consent of said dragon is required

contents.name: Floatstone

weapon_effect.base: When used in weapon crafting, when you release the weapon, it floats in the air instead of falling. If the weapon has to support any more weight than what the weapon itself weighs, then it falls normally.

contents.description: A weightless stone from the Floating Isles of the north, naturally attuned to the Plane of Air.

contents.name: Spectorium

weapon_effect.base: When used in weapon crafting, attacks you make with the weapon ignore half and two-thirds cover if you are within 5 feet of the target.

contents.description: Spectorium is a stone made of hyper compressed ethereal mists, found naturally within ethereal mountain ranges, though it can be made artificially with the proper facility and gear.

contents.name: Azure Lazulite

weapon_effect.base: Items crafted from Azure Lazulite never rust and cannot be destroyed by anything less than a deity. Only weapons and foci can be made from Azure Lazulite. You may use a weapon made from Azure Lazulite to attack an illusion. Make an attack roll against the spellcasters spell save DC. On a hit, the illusion is dispelled as if it was targeted by a successful Dispel Magic.

contents.description: Azure Lazulite is a unique form of the semi-precious lapis lazuli stone.

contents.name: Blackstone

weapon_effect.base: Weapons made of blackstone ignore any magical armor class increase (besides enchantments) their target has, but cannot benefit from any magical effect that raises or increases their attack roll (besides enchantments)

contents.description: Blackstone is a stone that is blacker than pitch, absorbing all light it comes across. Blackstone is a very rare material, infamous among smiths for its anti-magic properties.

contents.name: Bark/Wood
contents.description: Standard, mundane bark or wood. Gathered from a tree of your choosing.

contents.name: Untreated Bronzewood

weapon_effect.base: When used in weapon crafting, weapons made from untreated bronzewood can be used as druidic foci. However, they cannot be enchanted with focus enchantments.

contents.description: Bronzewood is a bronze-colored wood, native to the Southern Isle of Aurum. It is comparable in strength to bronze or brass, but is much lighter.
contents.tools_used: smithing tools or wood carving tools

contents.name: Treated Bronzewood

weapon_effect.base: When used in weapon crafting, weapons made from treated bronzewood can be used as druidic foci. However, they cannot be enchanted with focus enchantments.

contents.description: Treated Bronzewood has been treated with lakh resin, from the Northern Lakh Bug. This process causes the wood to harden dramatically, making it harder and more durable than steel.
contents.tools_used: smithing tools or wood carving tools

contents.name: Elven Leafweave
contents.description: Elven leafweave is made from layers of pressed forest leaves, which are then treated with a special alchemical process that makes them tough and flexible.
contents.tools_used: wood carving tools or herbalism kit

contents.name: Repentant Thorns

weapon_effect.base: Once per turn, you can give yourself advantage on an attack roll with the weapon. When you do so, you take an amount of piercing damage equal to the attack roll’s total

contents.description: Repentant Thorns are a thick collection of thorn and barb covered vines, wrapped and woven into the shape of a focus, armor or weapon.

contents.name: Chlorophyte

weapon_effect.base: As an attack with the weapon, you can fire a magical green projectile. Make a ranged spell attack with a range of 90 feet, on a hit, it deals an amount of force damage equal to the weapon’s damage dice plus any damage enchantments.

contents.description: Chlorophyte is a dark green, leafy, plant material that’s harder than steel. It’s found deep, deep underground beneath jungles and contains a large amount of druidic energy.
